ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 3 hrs.
About 3 hours
30 - midterm and final took more time of time 20 hours
5 hrs approximately
4-5hr
1-2 hours
9 hours per week
12 hrs
5 hours/week
With the homework about 2 to 3 hours per week.
2-3 hrs
Regularly: 1-2Final Paper last few weeks: 3-4 per wk

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: This course enhanced my appreciation of the complexity of epidemiological methods and the myriad issues which must be addressed in questionnaire design.

Good - I would have benefited from a clearer explanation of the expectations of the homework assignments earlier in the semester. It was initially unclear to me what the goal of the assignments were, and took me a few tries to get a handle on the expectations.

Really great breadth of material, and just enough depth. Some of the guest lecturers were less than stellar (ex: Biomarkers!). I did really like the structure of the course and thought a good deal of the material was useful and interesting.

This course provided a great overall of measurement issues in a variety of subject areas. I enjoyed having guest speakers come in to discuss specific areas of measurement, and the homework assignments properly assessed information learned in the curriculum.
strength: diversified.Weakness: not in-depth. The homework questions sometime seem to be not fitting well with the content in lecture.

This was a nice, broad overview of the important issues related to measurement of exposures and outcomes in epi research. It was a fundamental course with information that I will definitely use going forward.
Class was a bit choppy because of all the guest lecturers.

The course is a good introduction to methods for critically approaching measurement issues in public health. However, I would have liked a bit more depth rather than breadth. Each week introduced a new measurement topic, however, we never went deeper into the fine details as the semester progressed.

I enjoyed the fact that there were several guest speakers. It allowed us to hear about several diverse areas of research from different experts. I would, however, liked more of a discussion on general measruement issues like bias, sensitivity, specificity, population characteristics, etc.

This course covered measurement issues related to many different public health topics (CVD, obesity, nutrition, etc.). It was incredibly informative and best of all we got to hear from experts in each field about measurement issues specific to their field.I thought the homework assignments were really useful to help synthesize the material. The final paper was also a great way to delve deeply into measurement issues related to a topic of our choice.The only drawback to the course was the genetic/molecular epidemiology lecture. The guest lecturer clearly knew his field very well, but it was very difficult to understand him and for those of us who don't have any background in genetic/molecular epi, it was a very hard lecture to follow.It was not designed for a "beginner" audience.I would have also liked to have learned more about designing and evaluating a survey. We covered this briefly in the first two lectures, but did not go back to it afterwards. I am sure there are entire courses taught on designing surveys, but delving more deeply into the psychometrics of survey development would have been helpful, especially in writing our final papers.
good

I thought this course was excellent. It made me think about the practical side of carrying out research and made me see measurement issues in a totally different way. Some of the guest lecturers covered material that was not completely relavant to the course objective.
The lectures were helpful in expanding on the main topics, and the homeworks provided a good exercise and frame of reference for completing the midterm and final assignments.
I enjoyed how the course was organized with professors from different fields speaking about measurement issues in their respective fields.
I really liked this course. I think Dr. White is an excellent instructor. I would have liked her to give more lectures because she is such a great instructor.

The course was helpful in addressing measurement of disease processes, a concept with which I was unfamiliar prior to the course. It was helpful to have practicing professionals deliver many of the lectures in their area of expertise so that the students could relate to the issues involved with that particular area of practice.
I really enjoyed all the guest lecturers and how the material applied to different chronic diseases
Good information. Not all pertinent to everyone's area of study but good overall information.
The homework assignments were fairly tedious and did not provide much value. I did, however, learn a great deal from the assigned paper.

This course is very important, and I learned a lot about how to measure various issues within chronic disease epi. Most importantly, I learned about how to identify and use survey methods with good psychometric properties. I found this course interesting and invaluable.
covers a huge breadth of topicsI liked that experts in different fields were invited to give lectures on their topic
Good general overview of issues with measurement issues. Structurally the lecture order was kind of odd but I enjoyed the guest lecturers. Good way to have exposure a variety of faculty.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Marney A. White  Dr. White is one of the most engaging and talented professors I've had. Her wit and humor allow for a friendly learning environment, and her direct teaching style has earned her loyalty and respect from all her students. She inspires us to be better public health professionals (nobody wants to be the next Chip), and her ethics remind us of what it means to be a quality person.
Instructor: Marney A. White  The instructor only gave a few lectures, which were useful. She was responsive to questions outside of class.

Instructor: Marney A. White  Marney is awesome. Although I loved having guest lecturers because they knew a ton about their "field", I wish we could have gotten to hear more from Marney. She really knows her stuff and I enjoyed hearing her perspective. She was also very supportive and encouraging, and she set realistic expectations for us!

Instructor: Marney A. White  Marney did a wonderful job of giving lectures that were both informative and engaging. I especially enjoyed the stories and examples she used to illustrate concepts. Additionally, Marney was readily and easily available outside of the classroom. Whenever I had a question or concern, she responded quickly and helpfully.
Instructor: Marney A. White  Marney is responsible.
Instructor: Marney A. White  Dr. White is a terrific instructor. Her lectures were informative and actually fun.
Instructor: Marney A. White  okay but didn't lecture much. Did a good job at getting lectures together.
Instructor: Marney A. White  Dr. White is an excellent professor - course could not have been any better!
Instructor: Marney A. White  The instructor was knowledgeable but at times would get a bit off topic during the lectures.

Instructor: Marney A. White  Dr. White was a wonderful instructor. She made seeminglly dry course material enjoyable to learn about. The workload was appropriate, and she was always availabe to meet with students to discuss homework, final papers, etc.

Instructor: Marney A. White  Marney was great! She has a great sense of humor and understood that the material could get a bit dry. She was responsive to students and really cared about the class as a whole.
Instructor: Marney A. White  Fair
Instructor: Marney A. White  Marney is a smart professor, I wish she could give more of the lectures instead of guest speakers.
Instructor: Marney A. White  humous

Instructor: Marney A. White  Dr. White was a great teacher. Her material was very informative. When it got dry, she'd always inject humor to get the students into the material. She was very flexible and truly cares that students understand the material.

Instructor: Marney A. White  Dr. White was a great instructor providing useful examples to demonstrate points being made. The only draw back is that it was sometime difficult to hear her, as she speaks a little low.
Instructor: Marney A. White  She is awesome!
Instructor: Marney A. White  Marney was very approachable and helpful if you chose to seek advice from her.
Instructor: Marney A. White  Dr. White is a great instructor. I would like to see more lectures being given by her rather than guest lecturers. Side that, it was an excellent course.
Instructor: Marney A. White  Dr. White was easygoing and made the classroom atmosphere very relaxed, making participation easy.
Instructor: Marney A. White  Marney was very responsive to student questions and I really enjoyed her stories and how she related them to the lecture material.
Instructor: Marney A. White  She is great. A little all over the place when she lectures but she knows her stuff.
Instructor: Marney A. White  Very understanding and witty in her own way.
Instructor: Marney A. White  Dr. White takes a relatively mundane topic and makes it more engaging and informative.

Instructor: Marney A. White  The instructor was entertaining, had a good knowledge of the general subject of measurement in public health, and had good stories/sense of humor. My only complaint was that if sitting in the back of the room, the instructor was difficult to hear.
Instructor: Marney A. White  inspirationalwild sense of humorinspires reserach rigor and solid ethics

Instructor: Marney A. White  Very responsive and wants to help. Good lecturer and great with the students. Not really sure how I felt about the midterm as a reflection of what we had learned so far in the course but the final paper a great choice in terms of evaluation and reflection of all that we had learned in the year.

narratives.question_text: If this course included instruction by a teaching assistant (TA), please evaluate the TA here. What are the strengths and weaknesses and how might their teaching be improved? (Specify name of the TA).
comments: Erikka was always prepared, responsive, approachable, fair, professinoal, and an incredible resource. We are alll lucky that she decided to continue her studies at Yale.
The TA was responsive to questions outside of class, but at times the grading on the homework seemed a bit arbitrary.
Erikka was good. Sometimes the grading was a little confusing, but she was very organized, responsive, and knowledgeable.

Erikka was a helpful resource throughout the semester. While I rarely had questions to ask her, she arranged meetings and responded quickly to questions or concerns that came up throughout the semester.
TA: Erica.I didn't really have a lot of interaction with her.
The TA for this course was truly great. Very responsive and helpful.
Erikka - graded didn't have much interaction with her.
Erikka Loftfield - excellent TA!
The TA was very knowledgeable and helpful during office hours.
Erikka was great. She was responsive via email and it was easy to make an appointment with her. She also gave good feedback on the homework assignments.
Good
Too strict in homework.
The TA was very well informed on the subject and graded assignments in a timely fashion. There was no need for so much interaction outside of class.
Erikka Loftfeild : she is a good TA and gives good feedback on assignments
Erikka was great. She really knows the class material in and out and was very helpful when I had questions about course material.
The TA was fair but there were some inconsistencies in the grading of HWs. The comments sometimes didn't match the questions/topic on the HW.
Erikka was very helpful during office hours and took the time to help whenever it was needed. She was timely with returning assignments and fair with grading.
Erikka was very responsive to student questions and very helpful
The TA did not clearly articulate the expectations for the homework, which reflected poorly on initial homework grades.
The TA was excellent.
Erika, thank you for the efforts put into giving extensive feedback on the weekly homework!very approachable

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: The material in this course is useful for anyone considering a career in research and I would highly recommend it.
I have a better handle on measurement issues in a variety of settings than I did at the beginning of the semester.
Good course that covers a broad array of topics. Although this is a required course for CDE students, I would still recommend it because the material is useful and the coursework is not superfluous.

This course was a wonderful overview of the considerations that must be made when selecting, using, and reporting measurement techniques in epidemiology. You learn about a wide array of topic areas - cardiovascular disease, obesity, mortality, etc. - via lectures from guest speakers. These talks, along with Dr. White's introductory and summary lectures, provided a great overview of measurement issues in an engaging and informative way.
It is useful overall, except for a few lectures where the content is pretty much commonsense.
I would recommend this to other students because it provides basic information about how research can go wrong. Everybody to
okay. Weeks didn't build upon each other because of the different lecturers.
I would recommend this course as a great introduction to the complexities of measurement in epidemiology and public health.
Yes, I would definitely recommend to other students.
Good. The homework is sometimes reduplicate. Sometimes hard to find words different from last homework to answer the question.
If anyone wants to carry out research, I would say they should definitely take this course.
I found the course to be extremely useful, covering key issues critical epidemiologic research.
The course is useful and talks a lot of practical aspects but there are no new concepts covered over the course and the course could be expanded to include some skills as well.
It's a good course to take. You learn how to really pick apart measures in epidemiologic studies. The instructor is really great and makes the class very enjoyable.

I was initially unsure of the necessity of this course, however after taking it, I appreciate what I learned and believe that itwas good at emphasizing the themes of assessing measurements in different areas of public health practice.
This was a very useful course and I recommend it to anyone studying chronic disease.
Great overview of measurement issues and definitely helps with study preparation to think about these issues. Good course!
Useful
The course covers a very dry, but imperative topic: measurement.

The course covered general questionnaire design and psychometric properties (validity, reliability, specificity, etc.), and then went into detail about measurement of specifictopics by bringing in guest lecturers. Although the information on each specific subject tended to be cursory, this was ok because it's good to have an overview of all of these subjects even if you're not interested in particular issues covered.
extremely useful for solid research design
